channel.title: Research News@Emory
channel.description: All the latest news from Emory University.

item.title: 'Accidental Slaveowner' Has Roots in Oxford, Grounded in MARBL Research
item.description: Mark Auslander's story of Miss Kitty, an enslaved woman, and her connection to Emory is the subject of several events.

item.title: Emory Ethicist Nominated for World Technology Award
item.description: Paul Root Wolpe, director of Emory University's Center for Ethics, has been named a finalist for a prestigious World Technology Award in Ethics, to be presented by the World Technology Network at the United Nations next week.

item.title: Emory Hosts France-Atlanta 2011 Symposia on Kidney Disease Treatment
item.description: French and American scientists, academics and physicians will gather at Emory University in early November for two one-day conferences focusing on innovation in the treatment of chronic kidney disease across the globe. Both events are free and open to the public.

item.title: Conference on Maritime China Signals Shift in Scholarship of East Asian History
item.description: Top scholars from around the world will gather at Emory University for a conference on ChinaÂ¿s vast maritime trade and its impact on global history on Oct. 27-29.

item.title: Emory Vaccine Center Partners With Global Initiative to Boost Vaccine Research and Development
item.description: A team of 42 universities and research institutions in 13 countries will work to accelerate human vaccine development through a new collaborative research program named Advanced Immunization Technologies.

item.title: PODCAST: A Soldier Betrayed in Cuba's Struggle for Freedom
item.description: Emory English and African American Studies professor Mark Sanders edited and translated Afro-Cuban war veteran Ricardo Batrell's autobiography.

item.title: Emory Hosts Global Summit on Cardio-Metabolic Syndrome
item.description: Medical experts from around the world will gather at Emory University Oct. 13-14 to discuss the prevention and treatment of the rising global epidemic of cardio-metabolic syndrome.

item.title: NIH Awards Blueprint Training Grant in Computational Neuroscience
item.description: Faculty at Emory and Georgia Tech are training young scientists in how to use the tools of biomedical computation to solve challenging problems of neuroscience with a new five-year grant of $1.6 million from the National Institutes of Health.

item.title: Research Funding at Emory University Reaches Nearly $540M in FY11
item.description: Researchers at Emory University received $539.7 million from external funding agencies in fiscal year 2011, an increase from $535.1 million in fiscal year 2010.

item.title: Biochemical Cell Signals Quantified for First Time
item.description: Can you hear me now? When you feel symptoms of a nasty bug, you phone the doctor. Cells in your body are also receiving "calls," through a biochemical signaling pathway that turns out to have surprisingly low data capacity.

item.title: University-Industry Partnerships Drive Economic Impact, Improvements in Health Care
item.description: Emory University has joined other leading national academic institutions in a commitment to enhance university partnerships with industry, private foundations, venture capitalists, and government through technology transfer, entrepreneurship and economic development.

item.title: Emory Biologist Among Popular Science's 'Brilliant 10'
item.description: Emory University biologist Jaap de Roode is among this year's "Brilliant 10," top scientists under 40 recognized by the editors of Popular Science magazine.

item.title: Emory Sociologist to Study Racial Apathy
item.description: Tyrone Forman, an Emory University sociologist and co-director of the university's Race and Difference Initiative, has won a prestigious fellowship from Stanford University, serving as a visiting fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences in Palo Alto, Calif., for the 2011-2012 academic year.

item.title: Emory Again Ranked By U.S. News Among Top National Universities
item.description: Emory University is listed among the top 25 national universities for the 20th consecutive year in U.S. News & World Report's annual "Best Colleges" rankings published Sept. 13.

item.title: Hominid Skull Hints at Later Brain Evolution
item.description: An analysis of a skull from the most complete early hominid fossils ever found suggests that the large and complex human brain may have evolved more rapidly than previously realized.
